metadata.synopsis: The boss of an Iowa pajama factory hires superintendent Sid Sorokin (John Raitt) to help oppose the workers' demand for a seven-and-a-half-cent raise. Sid's handsome, affable presence stirs the jealousy of foreman Vernon Hines, who is dating bookkeeper Gladys Hotchkiss (Carol Haney), and attracts worker "Babe" Williams (Doris Day), a strong advocate for the pay increase. Despite liking Babe, Sid resists the workers' sabotage attempt and must decide whether to fire activist Babe.

reviews: [A] frequently-charming musical about a corporate manager.

A major problem with the picture is that all the performers who were apparently so wonderful on stage don't tone down the theatricality one iota for the big screen, resulting in plenty of unchecked and overbearing shrieking.
This is a delicious, bright and cheerful film.
It may not be especially distinguished filmmaking, but historically, it's a treasure trove.
As the two leads' flowering romance begins to grow further apart, the strain is conveyed through the mechanized perfectionism of the choreography.
Day particularly overdoes her schtick and sends the movie too often into self-parody
The Pajama Game may not be the greatest musical of all time..., but it's got some memorable songs and dances. And that's enough to carry the day.
Underappreciated musical gem. One of Day's best, and oh, the "Steam Heat" number!
One of the better musicals of its era, and a fascinating fusion of two disparate genres.
